articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This document is titled "EPHEMERIS" and appears to be a publication associated with "SJAA." Its cover features an astronomical photograph depicting stars and celestial objects against a dark sky, indicating a focus on celestial events, astronomy, or observational reports.

articles.title: UPCOMING EVENTS
articles.summary: This article outlines a busy schedule of upcoming events for the San Jose Astronomical Association and other regional astronomy groups. Highlights include a deep-sky astrophotography presentation, a Messier Marathon, an annual astronomical auction, a public Astronomy Day, upcoming eclipses, and major conferences like the Riverside Telescope Makers' Conference and a joint ASP/WAA/AANC meeting. The bulletin concludes with a farewell from the current editor.

articles.title: Letter to the Editor
articles.summary: This humorous letter to the editor presents a series of anecdotal observations about the tell-tale signs of an amateur astronomer's presence, from household habits like using 'BULB' mode on cameras and keeping film in the fridge, to dealing with common observing challenges such as dew and poor sites. It also includes a surreal personal update about an acquaintance and a request to publish a drawing of a 'Limburger Cheese Photometer.'

articles.title: DEEP SKY NOTES for MARCH
articles.summary: This article, "Deep Sky Notes for March" by Steve Gottlieb, provides an observing guide for the constellation Puppis, offering a final chance to view the tail end of the winter Milky Way. It details specific deep-sky targets, including open clusters M47, NGC 2423, M46 (with planetary nebula NGC 2438), and Merlotte 71, as well as the planetary nebula NGC 2440. Gottlieb shares personal observing notes, telescope recommendations, and visual descriptions for each celestial object.

articles.title: GREAT RED SPOT RECOVERED!
articles.summary: An observer successfully recovered Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) on February 19, noting its appearance after five months. The GRS appeared colorless, slightly north of its previous position, resting on the Southern Equatorial Belt with a small dent, and bounded by clear areas. Despite threatening weather, the sky was clear and steady for the observation.

articles.title: First Table
articles.summary: The document provides a schedule detailing the specific dates and times in March (PST) when Jupiter's Great Red Spot will transit the meridian. This table serves as a guide for observers interested in viewing this prominent feature on Jupiter.

articles.title: Second Table
articles.summary: This article provides a schedule of predicted meridian transit times for Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) during late March and early April, adjusted for Pacific Standard Time and optimal viewing conditions. It also offers detailed advice for amateur astronomers on how to observe the GRS, including equipment recommendations, techniques for identification, and tips for achieving the best views despite atmospheric turbulence.

articles.title: RESULTS!
articles.summary: This article reports on several grazing occultation expeditions, primarily focusing on two successful events in January 1984 involving v Virginis and 38 Aristis, despite challenging conditions for the former. It also briefly summarizes two 1983 grazes, one lost to clouds and another partially observed amid adverse weather. The author notes that full results and plots will be shared once completed.

articles.title: BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article by Don Machholz reports on a potential new comet discovery and details the visibility of several existing comets in March. It encourages observers to view Comets Crommelin and Encke in the evenings, tracks Comet Hartley-IRAS, and provides an update on Halley's Comet. Additionally, it discusses the status of recently discovered Comets Bradfield (1984a) and Clark (1984b), noting the latter's discovery is still unconfirmed.

articles.title: Ephemerides:
articles.summary: This document provides ephemerides, or astronomical tables, for two periodic comets: Crommelin (1983n) and Encke. It details their predicted positions (Right Ascension, Declination), elongation from the Sun, and apparent magnitude for early March and April. The article also includes descriptive notes on each comet's trajectory, observability, and specific relevance, such as Comet Crommelin serving as a test-run for Halley's Comet in 1985-86.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Hartley-IRAS (1983v)
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Periodic Comet Hartley-IRAS (1983v) for the period between March 1st and April 10th. It lists the comet's right ascension, declination, distance, and magnitude, noting its movement northward and higher in the morning sky for observers.

articles.title: PAST DISCOVERIES
articles.summary: This article analyzes comet discovery patterns by amateur astronomers between 1975 and 1983, highlighting both periods of rapid discovery, such as simultaneous finds in October 1975, and prolonged 'comet droughts'. A key focus is on how the Moon's phase influences discovery times, revealing distinct windows for evening discoveries (around 9 days after Full Moon and near New Moon) and morning discoveries (spanning a broader range after New Moon). This analysis suggests optimal lunar conditions for comet hunting.

articles.title: A VISIT TO LICK OBSERVATORY
articles.summary:
## A VISIT TO LICK OBSERVATORY

Even though Lick Observatory is right in our backyard, most of us have seldom visited it. And despite growing light pollution, Lick is still considered one of the world...

articles.title: Visitor's Viewing Room at Lick Observatory
articles.summary: This article describes a visitor's experience at Lick Observatory's Summer Visitor's Program, detailing lectures on the observatory's work and history, followed by viewing through the 36-inch and 40-inch refractors. The author recounts observing Jupiter and the globular cluster M13, noting the staff's friendliness and the lectures' informativeness. Practical instructions for obtaining tickets for the program are also provided, including contact details and application timing.

articles.title: SKYWORD PUZZLE #7
articles.summary: This document provides the complete list of answers for 'SKYWORD PUZZLE #7', categorized into 'DOWN' and 'ACROSS' sections. The answers include a wide range of astronomical terms, constellation names, celestial objects, and related concepts, with a correction for a previous month's clue.

articles.title: CALENDAR
articles.summary: This document is a calendar outlining various astronomy-related events scheduled for March, April, and May. It includes outdoor and indoor star parties, educational seminars and lecture series, general meetings, and special events like a Messier Marathon and an Annual Astronomical Auction. Events are sponsored by groups such as the Orange County Astronomers, SJAA, and the Astronomical Society of the Pacific, taking place at diverse locations across California.

articles.title: PRESENTED BY THE SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association announced an astronomy swap meet and auction scheduled for April 14, 1984, at the Leberon Hotel in San Jose. The event invited participants to buy and sell a wide array of astronomical equipment, books, camera gear, and space art, emphasizing its larger scale compared to previous years and its openness to everyone.

articles.title: PRE-REGISTRATION INFORMATION
articles.summary: This document provides detailed instructions for pre-registering items for an upcoming astronomical and telescope-making related auction scheduled for April 14. It outlines the process of filling out a form, mailing it with a SASE to Jim for item numbering, and the benefits of pre-registration, such as avoiding delays and receiving advanced advertising in the April bulletin. The article emphasizes pre-registration to ensure a smooth auction day.

articles.title: General meetings:
articles.summary: The document provides detailed directions to general meetings held at room 102 of the Alumni Science Hall, University of Santa Clara. It includes driving instructions from both northbound and southbound Hwy 17, along with specific parking and building entry details for attendees.

articles.title: Indoor Star Parties:
articles.summary: The article provides detailed location information and driving directions for "Indoor Star Parties" held at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building, located at 18011 Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd., Los Gatos. It includes specific instructions from Hwy 17 South, advising attendees to turn onto Rose Ave. to access the parking lot.

articles.title: Henry Coe State Park:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) observing site within Henry Coe State Park, accessible via the East Dunne exit from Hwy 101 South. It specifies the location of a locked gate on a dirt road, providing the combination (4565), and outlines rules for entry, particularly for arrivals after dark, emphasizing safety and minimal light use.

articles.title: Fremont Peak State Park:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Fremont Peak State Park, starting from Highway 101 South near Salinas, and guides visitors to the Coulter Camp overflow area. It specifically mentions the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) setting up there and includes a reminder about parking lights after dark.

articles.title: Space Station Gets Presidential Go-Ahead
articles.summary: President Reagan has directed NASA to begin development of a permanently manned U.S. space station within a decade, announcing the initiative during his January 25 State of the Union message. Estimated at $8 billion, with a target operational date of 1992, the station is envisioned for peaceful, economic, and scientific gains, with $150 million requested for fiscal year 1985. It will comprise core modules for living and laboratories, separate free-flying platforms for research and Earth viewing, and will be assembled via space shuttle launches to house 6-8 astronauts.

articles.title: NASA's FY 1985 Budget
articles.summary: The President has proposed a $1.49 billion budget for NASA for Fiscal Year 1985, which has been sent to Congress. This budget authorizes key projects including continued work on a space station, a Mars geoscience/climatology orbiter set for a 1990 launch, and an upper atmosphere research satellite planned for a 1989 launch.

articles.title: Shuttle Mission 41-b (STS-11) Has Mixed Results
articles.summary: Shuttle Mission 41-b (STS-11) experienced mixed results, including the deployment of two communications satellites into incorrect orbits due to upper stage motor failures, prompting NASA to consider a future recovery mission. Despite this setback, preparations for the Solar Maximum mission satellite retrieval went well, the new manned maneuvering units had successful first flights, and the shuttle completed its first landing back at the Kennedy launch site.

articles.title: Salyut 7 Manned Again
articles.summary: On February 8th, the Soviet Union launched a new three-man crew comprising Col. Leonid Kizim, Vladimir Solovyev, and Oleg Atkov. This crew successfully docked with the Salyut 7 Space Station on February 9th, re-manning the station.

articles.title: Chinese Spacecraft Launched
articles.summary: China successfully launched its 14th satellite on January 19. The spacecraft was placed into an orbit ranging from 223 to 4025 miles, inclined at 36 degrees.

articles.title: Japanese Launch Direct TV Broadcast Satellite
articles.summary: Japan successfully launched its BS-2A direct TV broadcast satellite, named Yuri-2A (Lily-2A), on January 23 using an N-2 launch vehicle. The satellite will be positioned at 110 east longitude, and a backup satellite is scheduled for an August launch.

articles.title: Hughes To Build 2 Direct TV Broadcast Satellites
articles.summary: Hughes has announced plans to construct and operate two 16-transponder satellites, seeking permission for the project. These satellites will be positioned at 118.8 and 119.2 degrees west longitude. Their primary purpose is to deliver direct-to-home television programming, with services expected to commence in 1989.

articles.title: NASA Drops 20/30 GHz Satellite Demonstration
articles.summary: NASA has abandoned its plans to demonstrate 20/30 GHz communication satellite operations. This decision comes after Hughes Aircraft company announced its intention to launch a privately funded satellite utilizing the same frequency band, rendering NASA's demonstration unnecessary.

articles.title: NASA and 3M Team-Up on Space Materials Processing
articles.summary: NASA and 3M have signed a memorandum of understanding to jointly develop commercial applications for materials processing in space. Under this agreement, two of 3M's materials processing experiments will be flown without charge, with the first flight potentially occurring in August.

articles.title: USAF Cancels July Shuttle Flight
articles.summary: The U.S. Air Force has canceled the 41-E space shuttle mission, originally scheduled for July 14, due to unresolved uncertainties regarding the readiness of the inertial upper stage. This decision impacts the planned space shuttle launch schedule.

articles.title: Next Shuttle Flight Scheduled for April 4, 1984
articles.summary: The next Space Shuttle Challenger flight, 41-C (STS-13), is scheduled for April 4, 1984. This six-day mission will deploy the Long Duration Exposure Facility (LDEF), which will be retrieved in January 1985, and also retrieve and repair the Solar Maximum Mission Satellite. The flight will carry a crew of five.

articles.title: LAndsat D Prime to be Launched in March
articles.summary: The Landsat D Prime Earth Resources Observation Satellite is scheduled for launch in March from Vandenberg Air Force Base using a Delta booster. This new satellite will replace the aging Landsat 4, which is experiencing significant power loss and multiple onboard failures.

articles.title: A SHORT HISTORY OF THE MESSIER MARATHON
articles.summary: This article details the brief history of the Messier Marathon, an astronomical challenge to observe nearly all of Charles Messier's catalogue of deep-sky objects in a single night. Starting as an idea in the late 1960s in Spain, the concept gained popularity in the mid-1970s with groups in Florida and Pittsburgh, evolving into a widespread dusk-to-dawn observing event aiming for 109 of 110 objects.

articles.title: Messier Marathon Article
articles.summary: This article details the history and evolution of the Messier Marathon, an astronomical observing challenge. It traces its origins from the author's suggestion in 1978 and early events with the San Jose Astronomical Association, through growing interest spurred by widely-published articles, to its later popularization by the Saguaro Astronomy Club. The article also provides key dates and locations for an upcoming Marathon, while noting past observation successes and challenges.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP
articles.summary: This document provides instructions for renewing San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) membership. Members are directed to send their renewal form, remittance, and an optional S&T white notice card to Treasurer Bob Fingerhut at his Milpitas address.

articles.title: SJAA MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION/RENEWAL
articles.summary: This document is an application and renewal form for membership in the SJAA organization. It requests personal contact information, an area of interest, and provides several membership tiers, including options for general membership, junior members, and a package likely including a Sky & Telescope magazine subscription.

articles.title: OBSERVATORY PLEDGE FUND
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is launching a pledge fund to support its long-standing Observatory Project, aiming to establish a permanent observing site. This site would house a 30-inch reflecting telescope, provide facilities like meeting areas, concrete pads for member instruments, and amenities such as a warm-up room and darkroom. The SJAA is seeking monthly pledges from members ($5-$20+) for 12 months, with an initial goal of raising $12,000, and is also requesting member input on site selection and features.

articles.title: Ads
articles.summary: The provided document consists of several classified advertisements for used astronomical equipment. Items for sale include various telescopes, such as a Meade Model 826 reflector, a Celestron C-8, and an 8" f/5 photographic Newtonian tube assembly. A range of accessories, including eyepieces, filters, motor drives, camera adapters, and a photographic star atlas, are also listed, with prices and contact details for each seller.

articles.title: BILLION DOLLAR QUESTION
articles.summary: This document, from the San Jose Astronomical Association's monthly publication "EPHEMERIS," includes a 1983 poem titled "BILLION DOLLAR QUESTION" from the Wall Street Journal, which humorously addresses the persistent challenge of toxic waste disposal. The majority of the page is dedicated to listing the association's officers and board of directors, complete with contact information, characteristic of an internal newsletter or bulletin.

articles.title: Bob Fingerhut has been keeping tabs on what renewing and new member have put on their membership renewal forms as to what their major interest(s) are. Curious? Below are listed all the catagories that were written in.
articles.summary: Bob Fingerhut has compiled a list of major astronomical interests indicated by renewing and new members on their membership forms. The data reveals a diverse range of activities, with 'Observing' and 'Astrophotography' being the most popular among the listed categories. This compilation highlights the varied interests within the SJAA organization.

articles.title: Commercial ads are priced according to size and may be placed by contacting: Gene Cisneros at (408) 923-6800.
articles.summary: This document provides information on placing commercial advertisements, stating that pricing is determined by size, and directs interested parties to contact Gene Cisneros at (408) 923-6800 for placement.

articles.title: LUMICONÂ®
articles.summary: LUMICON promotes itself as a "World Center for Astrophotography" and a leading provider of in-stock telescopes and accessories in the West. The company, based in Livermore, CA, emphasizes its "Innovation In Astronomy," particularly highlighting its Deep-Sky Filters and eyepieces, manufactured locally. They invite customers to visit or call for their complete selection and information on over 50 unique astronomical filter systems.

articles.title: ATM coatings
articles.summary: This document is an advertisement for ATM Coatings, a company located in Oakland, CA, specializing in aluminum coatings with silicon monoxide over-coating for telescope mirrors. It provides a price list for various mirror sizes, notes that secondary mirrors are coated for free when sent with a primary, and details additional charges for old coating removal and minimum service fees, along with shipping instructions.

articles.title: OPTRON SYSTEMS
articles.summary: OPTRON SYSTEMS is an advertisement for a retail store located in San Jose, CA, specializing in astronomical equipment and accessories. They offer products from numerous well-known brands such as Bushnell, Celestron, Meade, Lumicon, Orion, and Tele-Vue Optics, catering to the needs of astronomers.

articles.title: SAN JOSE, CA 95124
articles.summary: This document fragment appears to be a mailing header or indicia for a news publication originating from San Jose, California. It specifies that the content is time-sensitive news material being distributed via U.S. bulk rate postage with a local San Jose permit.
